25 years ago I worked in agriculture harvesting strawberries for a local farmer, side by side with migrant workers. He paid by pint to anyone who showed up, and lots of local kids worked his fields in the summer. I usually made about $10-$15 in a 7 hour day, which was enough for me as a middle schooler. The migrant workers, though, working to support their families back home, usually made ten times as much, sometimes upwards of twenty times as much. Now, comparing a teens work to that of an adult may not be fair, but the migrants I knew worked incredibly hard and still had energy to play basketball with me on the outdoor courts of the local elementary school in the afternoons. Do we protect Americans and deny success to such strivers?

Personally, I side with the migrants.

We had work done on our house a half dozen years ago....it was interesting to see the work ethic of native white construction workers who showed up to work rather late @ 9 or even 10 am, then leave by 3 pm daily did an ok, but not earth shattering job).....whereas Mexican and Central Americans that worked on the landscaping, arrived @ 7:30 am, took a 30 min lunch, and went right back to work until 5 pm. I admired the Hispanics for their work ethic and positive attitude...I would hire them again in a snap.

We probably didn't have pay as high a price as we did for the construction had the (white) construction crew worked longer hours daily - the job took almost a year. Whereas the extensive landscaping and stone work took just 6 amazing weeks...

We have endeavored to hire local whites (there are few if any blacks in the area) to mow the lawn, paint the house, etc....not only to they quote crazy prices, they are not reliable and the service they offer is inconsistent. So again, we are happy to call on aa Equadoran (with immigration papers) to paint....he never forgets to stop by to give us an estimate, usually not cheap, but reasonable and worth every penny, given that the quality is excellent and he and his team actually show up when they say they will.

I am torn about the immigration debate - concerned about the costs, about our changing culture, etc....but then I think again about how hard new immigrants work and know that they are and will be good for our country.

That's not true.  We already do this.  Our food prices have increased since 2008.  The packages have gotten smaller, the cost per lb have gone up.  We still buy food.  Produce is some of the most expensive items I purchase.  The meat is very high-- traditionally cheaper cuts of meat are no longer cheap.

The bottom line is that Americans won't pay one cent more for produce, meat or any other product that involves difficult labor, in order to provide a workplace that their fellow Americans can work in without losing dignity and being paid like peons.  The most liberal among us will shriek, "OMG, NO!!!" if their strawberries cost a dime more or a pack of Fruit o' the Looms goes up 25 cents.  Don't blame the farmers; they have to compete to sell to people (Americans) who care not one whit for social justice, only how cheaply they can get their goodies.

It's not a matter of "working together" -- it's a matter of Americans realizing, and acknowledging -- that fairness costs money.  You gotta pay a little more for that lettuce if you want field workers to get a fair shake.  And you know what? Americans from every part of the political spectrum don't want to do that.

How about Ferguson's remark about Keynes' "long run" remark reflecting childless homosexuality? It's ignorant on so many levels, but also disingenuously suggests Keynesian interest in fixing the economy now ignores the subsequent burdens placed on the future for so doing. But in fact the more quickly people are put back to work, the less productivity loss "in the long run." Otherwise, it's like suggesting one keep one's eyes closed during bad times, because you won't use up that time now and will have it later on. Productivity lost is lost, not postponed - at least as far as the human element goes. (Machinery, resources, etc may be another matter).

Judging from the comments Brian Stanley has written an excellent piece for all of us to project our own interpretations on. So I think I'll have a go.

This to me points to a much deeper meaning in the essay.

The brain is not synonymous with the self, nor is the body. A first step may be to view them as a canvas on which the mind is painted. And I could say that the image of the painting is the mind, but I must tacitly that the image has no true existence without the canvas. But even this does not capture what the mind is to the body.

We are increasingly establishing both in studying the more rudimentary intelligence of other animals and automata of our creation, and in investigating the mechanism of our own thought that these are not manifest as concrete matter, but rather as dynamic patterns.

Our minds are rather more like music. They cannot exist without some instrument to produce them, and just as a single note in isolation has little meaning, so a mind is a creature tied to time. The mind is ephemeral by its very nature.

Stanley's essay is about how bizarre it is that our minds, which alone can understand the implication of it all are so at the mercy of their more concrete vessels. Doomed to be outlasted and destroyed.

I don't think the intent of this vote is to give the National Council power in deciding who should be a local leader. It would, I assume, give them oversight power should someone be discriminated against based on his sexuality. Under our national laws, the gov't can't tell an employer whom to hire to do a job unless the employer has refused to hire, say, qualified African-Americans.  Now some still believe that African-Americans are inherently unqualified to do certain kinds of jobs precisely because they are of black heritage. The law says you can think that if you like, but you can't act on it in hiring. The criteria that the opponents of gays in Scouting want to continue to use say that, inherently, homosexuals lack the qualifications to be a Scout leader (or until now, even a member) because of who they are and should systematically be denied involvement in Scouting. Firstly, that is ridiculous, since plenty of gays have been successful Scouts. They were qualified. Secondly, that is discrimination against a group based on the beliefs of certain religious leaders, but not all, giving preference to the religious beliefs of certain people involved in Scouting, as Mr. Bruni points out. That contradicts the supposed ideals of Scouting. What it really comes down to is the need for certain people in Scouting, in every part of our society, to come up with a justification for their own discriminatory practices, a need within themselves they never question, and ought to.

I would support lifting the ban on both gay scouts and gay scout leaders, and allowing troops to select appropriate leaders at the local level. If a troop is sponsored by a religious organization, presumably troop leadership acceptable to the sponsoring organization can be found. At the same time, the Boy Scouts' National Council should not be passing judgment on a local troop's decision of whether or not to employ a gay scout leader, nor should one local troop have the ability to require that another local troop follow its dictates on gay leadership.

In sum, I'd leave the gay leadership decision to the local sponsoring organization, as there are clearly diverse views on this subject.

The resolution doesn't seem to add up. The Chinese had ventured 19 km inside Indian territory. They have now retreated. Why did the Indians need to retreat? They should have in fact advanced to survey what the Chinese did to what is theirs, inspecting for land mines etc. for example.

The Chinese had earlier asked the Indians to either halt or cut back on the "infrastructure development" in the region of Daulat Beg Oldi, including the refurbishment of an airstrip that hasn't been used for 50 years.

As a concession, have the Indians agreed to cut back on the infrastructure development? Worse yet, have the Indians in the process implicitly agreed that the 19 km swath of land is now no-man's land?
